name: Intermediate Research Software Development (Python)
description: A core set of established, intermediate-level software development skills and best practices for working as part of a team in a research environment using Python as an example programming language.
keywords: programming language, python, intermediate, software engineering, testing, debugging, version control, continuous integration, packaging code, releasing code, integrated development environment, IDE, virtual environment, git, github, good practices, action, CI/CD, automation, reproducible environment
author: Aleksandra Nenadic, Steve Crouch, Thomas Kile, Raniere Silv, François Michonnea, Maxim Belkin, James Graham, Greg Wilson, Matthew, Toby Hodges, Zhian N. Kamvar, Sven van der Burg, Abby Cabunoc Mayes, JacalynLair, Sarah Stevens, Katrin Leinweber, Erin Becker, João Rodrigues, Douglas Lowe, Sam Mangham, Rayna M Harris, Matthew Blutea, Renato Alv, Sander van Rijn, Rémi Emon, David Mawdsley, Piotr Banaszkiewi, Jemma Stachelek, Giulia Crocion, William L. Close
contributor: anenadic, steve-crouch, thomaskileyukaea, bielsnohr, jag1g13, tobyhodges, svenvanderburg, JacalynLaird, sstevens2, douglowe, smangham, knarrff, sjvrijn, gcroci2, hsaunders1904, tomneep, unode, danielskatz, amangoel185, wk9874, jreeve-nv, gkmurphy, sverchkov, shartleybham-acuk, gadgil48, olexandr-konovalov, martinjrobins, kzscisoft, k-collie, guyer
teaches: Document and structure your software, collaborate to develop, prepare software for others to use.

name: Alan Turing Institute - Research Software Engineering with Python
description: In this course, you will move beyond programming, to learn how to construct reliable, readable, efficient research software in a collaborative environment. The emphasis is on practical techniques, tips, and technologies to effectively build and maintain complex code. This is a relatively short course (8-10 half-day modules) which is intensive and involves hands-on exercises.
keywords: research software engineering, programming language, python, collaborative environment

name:
“Good
Enough Practices in Scientific Computing” course
description: This lesson is targeted at a broad audience of researchers who want to learn how to be more efficient and effective in their data analysis and computing, whatever their career stage.
keywords: readable code, data analysis, computing, research, data management, collaboration, project organization, manuscripts

name: Five recommendations for FAIR software, by the Netherlands eScience Center and DANS
description: Five recommendations for FAIR software, by the Netherlands eScience Center and DANS
keywords: fair, version control, license, registry, repository, citation, checklist

name: A self-assessment checklist for FAIR research software
description: A self-assessment checklist for FAIR research software
keywords: fair, self-assessment, checklist, research software

name:
Open source definition, by the Open Source
Initiative
description: A ten-point description of Open Source by the open source initiative®.
keywords: open source, code, license, software

name:
CodeRefinery:
Reproducible research - preparing code to be usable by you and others in
the future
description: In this lesson we will explore different methods and tools for better reproducibility in research software and data. We will demonstrate how version control, workflows, containers, and package managers can be used to record reproducible environments and computational steps for our future selves and others.
keywords: readable code, organise software project, reproducible environment

name: Top 10 FAIR Data & Software Things
description: Brief guides for different disciplines that can be used by the research community to understand how they can make their research (data and software) more FAIR
keywords: fair, data, research software engineers

name: The FAIR Cookbook, online recipes for life scientists that help make and keep data FAIR
description: An online, open and live resource for the Life Sciences with recipes that help you to make and keep data Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable; in one word FAIR.
keywords: fair, life sciences, infrastructure, assessment

name: 10 easy things to make your research software FAIR
description: Ten easy things to make your software FAIR.
keywords: fair, software

name:
Cookiecutter software project template to kickstart a modern best-practice
Python project with FAIR metadata
description: An opinionated cookiecutter template to kickstart a modern best-practice Python project with FAIR metadata.
keywords: fair, metadata, python, programming language, codemeta, cff, reuse, citation

name: Course: ResOps - Cloud-native Tools and Technology for Researchers
description: This course provides some background to cloud computing and practical experience in building, deploying and running applications in cloud platforms - OpenStack, Google, Amazon and Azure.
keywords: reproducible environments, cloud, docker, kubernetes, version control, gitlab

name: Introduction to the Command Line for Metagenomics
description: This workshop will answer these questions (and more): What is a command shell and why would I use one? How can I perform operations on files outside of my working directory? What are some navigational shortcuts I can use to make my work more efficient? How can I control who has permission to modify a file? How can I repeat recently used commands? How can I search within files? How can I combine existing commands to do new things? How can we automate a commonly used set of commands? How can we transfer files between local and remote computers?
keywords: cli, command line, metagenomics, shell, scripts, data, project organization

name: Introduction to R
description: This workshop will answer these questions: What is R, and why is important to learn to use it? What types of data does the R language has? What types of data does the R language have? What are they, and how to manage them? How can I create useful graphs in R? How can I ask R for help?
keywords: programming language, R, metagenomics

name: Tutorial: Workflows - Combining Tools for Data Analysis
description: This tutorial provides a short introduction to workflows for the analysis of life sciences data, providing examples of platforms for creating workflows and the considerations required for developing them. This tutorial is for anyone who would like to learn about the role of workflows in the analysis of life sciences data.
keywords: computational workflows, data analysis

name: ENSEMBL REST API course
description: This course uses Jupyter Notebooks hosted by Google Colab to walk you through the APIs and practise writing scripts to access these data. A video provides a brief overview of the REST API, endpoints and instructions on working with the Jupyter notebooks. This is an intermediate to advanced level course and requires some familiarity with Ensembl, REST APIs and the ability to program in Python or R. We won’t teach you how to code in this course, just how to use your existing coding knowledge to access Ensembl data. If you would like an introduction to Ensembl then we recommend watching our Ensembl Browser Webinar Series.
keywords: ensembl, rest api, python, R

name: "Ten Reproducible Research Things" Tutorial
description: This self-paced tutorial outlines ten steps to make your research reproducible, beginning with data quality, documentation, management of sensitive data, through to the publication of datasets. The aim is to move towards reproducible research regardless of your current skills, and includes useful resources for beginners, intermediate and advanced learners.
keywords: version control, documentation, data quality, backup, security, documentation, conventions, structure, automation, version control, persistent identifiers

name: The Turing Way: A handbook for reproducible, ethical and collaborative research
description: This guide covers topics related to skills, tools and best practices for research reproducibility.
keywords: version control, git, licensing, reproducible environments, documentation, quality, testing, continuous integration, static code analysis

name: “How Git Works” course on Pluralsight
description: This course is for developers and system administrators who want to really understand Git. Whether you just started using Git, or you've been using it every day for months - this course will give you the knowledge you need to become a Git master.
keywords: version, control, git, github

name: Introduction to User Experience Design
description: This course introduces user experience design (UXD) in the context of bioinformatics tools and service development. It provides an overview of basic concepts and links to external resources on UXD where you can learn more. This course is for anyone who would like to learn about user experience design; particularly biocurators, developers, bioinformaticians and researchers who are involved in biocuration and the process of creating bioinformatics tools and resources that use biological data will find this training useful.
keywords: user experience design, uxd, bioinformatics, user experience, ux, biocuration, biological data

name: GPU Programming
description: The objectives of this course is to understand the differences between CPU and GPU and see the possible performance benefits of GPU acceleration
keywords: gpu programming, gpu, cpu, cupy, python, numba, memory

name: Parallel Programming in Python
description: The objectives of this course is to recognize serial and parallel patterns, identify problems that can be parallelized, understand a dependency diagram.
keywords: parallel programming, python, serial, dependency diagram

name: GPU Programming: When, Why and How?
description: This material is meant to help both software developers and decision makers navigate the GPU programming landscape and make more informed decisions on which languages or frameworks to learn and use for their projects. Specifically, you will: understand why and when to use GPUs; become comfortable with key concepts in GPU programming; acquire a comprehensive overview of different software frameworks, what levels they operate at, and which to use when; learn the fundamentals in at least one framework to a level which will enable you to quickly become a productive GPU programmer.
keywords: gpu programming, gpu, hpc

name: CUDA training
description: This course is for students, researchers, engineers and programmers who would like to learn GPU programming with CUDA. Some previous experience with C/C++ is required, no prior knowledge of CUDA is needed.
keywords: gpu programming, gpu, cuda, c, c++, vectors

name: OpenACC training
description: This lesson is an introduction to GPU programming using the directive-based OpenACC paradigm. The course consists of lectures, type-along and hands-on exercises. Topics covered include the architecture of the GPU accelerators, basic usage of OpenACC, and how to control data movement between CPUs and GPUs. Basic optimization of the code will also be covered. After the course the participants should have the basic skills needed for utilising OpenACC with new or existing programs. The participants are assumed to have knowledge of Fortran and/or C programming languages. Since participants will be using HPC clusters to run the examples, fluent operation in a Linux/Unix environment is assumed.
keywords: gpu programming, gpu, open acc, c, c++, fortran, supercomputers, bash, makefile

name: Introduction to Julia
description: This lesson covers the basics of Julia: its syntax, multiple-dispatch paradigm, package development and best practices. This lesson is appropriate for researchers, engineers and analysts from academia, industry or the public sector who want to adopt a new programming language into their repertoire. It also represents the prerequisite knowledge to follow other ENCCS lessons on Julia - Julia for High Performance Scientific Computing and Julia for High Performance Data Analysis.
keywords: programming language, julia, computing, hpc

name: Julia for high-performance scientific computing
description: This lesson goes through various approaches for writing performant and parallel code, including how to write fast serial code, how to write multithreaded and distributed code, how to run Julia on an HPC system, and how to port Julia code to GPUs.
keywords: programming language, julia, hpc, gpu computing

name: Julia for high-performance data analytics
description: This lesson starts with a discussion of working with data in Julia, how to use the DataFrames.jl package and how to visualise data. It then moves on to linear algebra approaches, followed by classical machine learning approaches as well as deep learning methods with an example of scientific ML. Finally, key aspects of regression, time series prediction and analysis is covered.
keywords: programming language, julia, hpc, gpu

name: Programming with Julia
description: This lesson will explain the difference between interpreted and compiled programming languages and compare how composing works in Julia and some common programming languages.
keywords: programming language, julia, packaging, module

name: Automation and Make
description: The objectives of this lesson are to: Recognize the key parts of a Makefile, rules, targets, dependencies and actions; write a simple Makefile; run Make from the shell; explain when and why to mark targets as .PHONY.; explain constraints on dependencies.
keywords: makefile, shell, compile

name: CMake hands-on workshop
description: This course is for students, researchers, engineers, and programmers that have heard of CMake and want to learn how to use it effectively with projects they are working on. This course assumes no previous experience with CMake. You will have to be familiar with the tools commonly used to build software in your compiled language of choice: C++, C, Fortran.
keywords: programming language, cmake, c, c++, testing

name: Software Carpentry: Git Novice lesson
description: Version control is the lab notebook of the digital world: it’s what professionals use to keep track of what they’ve done and to collaborate with other people. Every large software development project relies on it, and most programmers use it for their small jobs as well. And it isn’t just for software: books, papers, small data sets, and anything that changes over time or needs to be shared can and should be stored in a version control system.
keywords: version, control, git, github, licensing

name: CodeRefinery: Collaborative distributed version control
description: We have learned how to work with a Git repository used by a single person. What about sharing and collaborating?
keywords: version, control, git, github

name: CodeRefinery: Introduction to version control
description: Introduction to version control with Git - Why we want to track versions and how to go back in time to a working version
keywords: version, control, git, github

name: Continuous Integration / Continuous Development (CI/CD)
description: GitLab is a git platform used for code hosting and collaboration. It can be used to automatically run checks and other code or workflows on GitLab’s servers. We’ll learn how to use this to make our code robust to errors, preserved, and reproducible.
keywords: gitlab, collaboration, workflow, reproducibility, CI/CD

name: Python Testing and Continuous Integration
description: In this lesson we use a Python library called pytest. Basic understanding of Python variables and functions are a necessary prerequisite. Some previous experience with the shell is expected, but isn’t mandatory.
keywords: python, pytest, testing, automation, continuous integration, CI/CD

name: Workflows with Python and Git
description: In this lesson, we will apply use of functions, conditionals and loops to solve a problem.
keywords: programming language, python, version control

name: Introduction to Cloud Computing for Genomics
description: In this lesson, you’ll learn about renting cloud services that fit your analytic needs, and how to interact with one of those services (AWS) via the command line.
keywords: cloud, genomics, aws, cli, data

name:
Software Carpentry: Introduction
to Workflows with Common Workflow Language
description: This tutorial guides you through the the fundamentals of designing and building an analysis workflow. It assumes no previous knowledge or experience of workflows or Common Workflow Language (CWL), but does assume some experience with the Unix command line.
keywords: workflows, common workflow language, cwl, unix, cli

name: Software Carpentry: Programming with Python
description: The best way to learn how to program is to do something useful, so this introduction to Python is built around a common scientific task: data analysis.
keywords: programming language, python

name:
Software Carpentry: Plotting and
Programming in Python
description: The lesson will teach you how to Launch the JupyterLab server; create a new Python script; create a Jupyter notebook, shutdown the JupyterLab server; understand the difference between a Python script and a Jupyter notebook; create Markdown cells in a notebook; create and run Python cells in a notebook.
keywords: programming language, python, jupyterlab, python script

name: Level Up your Python
description: A course in intermediate Python for a beginner ready to move up. Binder version and Live WebAssembly version available too!
keywords: programming language, python

name: Library Carpentry: Python Intro for Libraries
description: This lesson is an introduction to programming in Python for library and information workers with little or no previous programming experience. It uses examples that are relevant to a range of library use cases, and is designed as a prerequisite for other Python lessons that will be developed in the future (e.g., web scraping, APIs). The lesson uses the JupyterLab computing environment and Python 3.
keywords: programming language, python

name: Building Better Scientific Software in Python
description: The goal of this tutorial is to expose researchers to several best practices in scientific software engineering that may otherwise take several years to become acquainted with. Though the implementation of these lessons is Python-specific, the essential ideas can be exported to other languages or platforms.
keywords: programming language, python, packaging, testing, documentation, logging, performance

name:
Software Carpentry: R for
Reproducible Scientific Analysis
description: The goal of this lesson is to teach novice programmers to write modular code and best practices for using R for data analysis
keywords: programming language, R, reproducibility

name: Software Carpentry: Programming with R
description: The best way to learn how to program is to do something useful, so this introduction to R is built around a common scientific task: data analysis. Our real goal isn’t to teach you R, but to teach you the basic concepts that all programming depends on
keywords: programming language, R

name: Getting Used to R, RStudio, and R Markdown
description: This material  was written to give people who are new to R, RStudio, and R Markdown the tools they need to begin making their own research reproducible
keywords: programming language, R

name: Modern Dive into R and the Tidyverse
description: This online handbook aims at providing statistical inference via data science using R and Tidyverse
keywords: programming language, R

name:
Software Carpentry: Programming
with MATLAB
description: The best way to learn how to program is to do something useful, so this introduction to MATLAB is built around a common scientific task: data analysis. Our real goal isn’t to teach you MATLAB, but to teach you the basic concepts that all programming depends on.
keywords: programming language, MATLAB

name: Introduction to the Internet of Things
description: In this lesson, your will learn: About IoT ; Arduino Nano architecture and Arduino GUI; Learn to blink the internal led of an Arduino Nano; Learn to create a simple weather station with an Arduino Nano
keywords: internet of things, arduino, arduino nano

name: Automated Testing - Preventing Yourself and others from Breaking your Functioning Code
description: This lesson will talk about the places it’s useful for research code, and how easy it can be. We will discuss why testing often needs to be part of the software development cycle and how such a cycle can be implemented. We will see how automated testing works and practice designing and writing tests.
keywords: testing, continuous integration, automation, python

name: How to Document your Research Software
description: This lesson discusses different solutions for implementing and deploying code documentation.
keywords: documentation, readme, readthedocs, github pages

name: CodeRefinery: Software Citation
description: This resource will help you untangle these questions: Is putting software on GitHub/GitLab/… publishing? Where to publish software? How can software be cited? How can I make my software citeable?
keywords: citation, publishing, releasing, fair

name: CodeRefinery: Software Licensing
description: A course on software licensing
keywords: license

name: SQL for Humanities
description: This lesson will teach you what relational databases are, how you can load data into them and how you can query databases to extract just the information that you need.
keywords: database, SQL, data

name: SQL for Business
description: This lesson will teach you what relational databases are, how you can load data into them and how you can query databases to extract just the information that you need.
keywords: sql, business, database, quality control

name:
Software Carpentry: Database and
SQL
description: These lessons will show how to use a database to explore the expeditions’ data.
keywords: database, sql, data, python, R

name:
CodeRefinery: Jupyter Notebooks - A tool to write
and share executable notebooks and data visualization
description: The goal of this lesson is to teach learners the user interface of JupyterLab, how Jupyter notebooks work, and what some common and powerful use cases are.
keywords: jupyter notebook, notebooks, data visualization, jupyterlab

name: Python Packaging
description: This lesson teaches how to create and publish packages in Python
keywords: package, packaging, release, python

name: Managing Academic Software Development
description: This workshop teaches the basics of managing project development and release, using the project management tools on the repository hosting site GitHub (and is applicable to repositories hosted on GitLab).
keywords: release, git, github, gitlab, identifiers, version

name:
Software Carpentry: Managing
Research Software Projects
description: Introduction to the basics of software project management with a particular focus on the sorts of projects commonly found in research settings. Participants should have previously worked on programs containing thousands or tens of thousands of lines of code, and be regular users of basic tools like the Unix shell and a version control system. Building on that foundation, this course will discuss:
keywords: license, version control, continous integration, robust, code review, testing

name:
Reproducible
Computational Environments using Containers: Introduction to Singularity
description: This lesson provides an introduction to using the Singularity container platform. Singularity is particularly suited to running containers on infrastructure where users don’t have administrative privileges, for example shared infrastructure such as High Performance Computing (HPC) clusters.
keywords: container, reproducible environment, reproducibility, singularity, HPC

name:
Reproducible
Computational Environments Using Containers: Introduction to Docker
description: This material aims to introduce the use of Docker containers with the goal of using them to effect reproducible computational environments. Such environments are useful for ensuring reproducible research outputs, for example.
keywords: docker, container, reproducible environment, reproducibility, singularity

name:
Introduction
to Docker and Podman
description: An introduction to using Docker and Podman as software development tools.
keywords: This material is an introduction to machin learning with Python. Topics are: Unsupervised Learning: dimensionality reductiong; unsupervised Learning: clustering; supervised Learning: basic methods; supervised Learning: using real data and preprocessing

name: Welcome to Python Packages
description: Python packages are a core element of the Python programming language and are how you create organized, reusable, and shareable code in Python. Python Packages is an open source book that describes modern and efficient workflows for creating Python packages.
keywords: programming language, python, packaging, package, release

name: Tools and Practices for FAIR Research Software
description: This short course is teaching tools and practices for producing and sharing quality, sustainable and FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable) research software to support open and reproducible research.
keywords: FAIR, documentation, reproducible environment, readable code, documentation

name: Modern Scientific C++
description: This training material addresses modern scientific computing in C++, for people who already have some experience in legacy C++ programming (before C++ 11)
keywords: programming language, c++

name: Cpp17 Initiation for Pythonists
description: This training material addresses modern scientific computing in C++, for people who already have some experience in legacy C++ programming (before C++ 11):
keywords: programming language, c++, scientific computin

name: Python Traps and Pitfalls
description: A closer look at the basic mechanisms of the Python language, beyond what can be guessed by blindly copying and pasting examples, in order to avoid the most common traps and pitfalls
keywords: programming language, python

name: Introduction to Machine Learning
description: This material is an introduction to machin learning with Python. Unsupervised Learnin: dimensionality reductiongUnsupervised Learning: clusteringSupervised Learning: basic methodsSupervised Learning: using real dataPreprocessing
keywords: programming language, Python, unsupervised learning, supervised learning, preprocessing

name: Introduction to Deep Learning
description: This material is an introduction to deep learning with Python. Two main topics are covered: Multi Layer Perceptron and Convolution Neural Network.
keywords: machine learning, deep learning, Python, multi layer perceptron, convolution neural network

name: Make your code more efficient
description: Material for a two-mornings performance optimization training
keywords: performance, benchmarking, profiling, optimization

name: Make your code more robust
description: Tools and methodologies to write code that is easier to understand and maintain.
keywords: readable code, testing, documentation, continuous integration

name: Web Interfaces Development in a Nutshell
description: Welcome to the Web Interfaces Development in a Nutshell course! This course is designed to provide you with a comprehensive introduction to the world of web development. We will cover a wide range of topics, including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and more. By the end of this course, you will be able to create your own webpage from scratch and understand the basics of web development.
keywords: web interfaces, html, css, javascript, Python, Django, RESTful API, blog

name: Git Survival Guide
description: This guide offers a curated collection of exercises aimed at helping you learn and practice Git commands and workflows effectively.
keywords: version control, git, gitlab

name: GitLab and GitLab CI/CD
description: A course designed to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of GitLab and GitLab CI/CD
keywords: task automation, gitlab, CI/CD, continuous integration

name: Foundational HPC Skills (DIRAC)
description: A basic introduction to the principles of HPC and the tools needed to work on an HPC system. The training will help you to develop the skills required to meet your research needs and enable you to utilise DiRAC’s HPC systems effectively. The course focuses on core skills, from basic connection to a system, to laying the foundation for developing robust, high-quality code. We assume familiarity with desktop computers, but no prior programming, Linux or HPC experience is required.
keywords: version control, git, testing, documentation, HPC

name: CodeRefinery - training and e-Infrastructure for research software development
description: We train you in research software development Are you an academic researcher using computing/data, and your work is held back by struggling with the programming or data management? Or your research isn't reproducible or open enough? CodeRefinery understands and has free online courses and materials for you. We teach all the essential tools which are usually skipped in academic education so everyone can make full use of software, computing, and data with focus on reusability, reproducibility, and openness. We don't just give courses, but we are a training network that you can join to share the effort and bring better courses to your community. Our standard workshop is well known in Nordic academic circles and our engaging online teaching style is considered best-in-class even compared to in-person teaching. CodeRefinery is publicly funded and operates as a community project.
keywords: research software development, academic, reproducibility, open, lessons, workshops, tasks

name: Software Carpentry
description: Software Carpentry is a lesson program within The Carpentries teaching basic lab skills for research computing.
keywords: lessons, carpentries, lab skills, research computing, research software, unix, git, Python, R, reproducibility, Make, Matlab, SQL

name: Data Carpentry
description: Data Carpentry workshops are domain-specific, so that we are teaching researchers the skills most relevant to their domain and using examples from their type of work. Therefore we have several types of workshops and curriculum is organised by domain.
keywords: lessons, carpentries, workshops, research software, curriculum, data, astronomy, ecology, genomics, geospatial, image processing, social science, SQL, R, Python

name: Library Carpentry
description: Library Carpentry workshops teach people working in library- and information-related roles how to: Cut through the jargon terms and phrases of software development and data science and apply concepts from these fields in library tasks. Identify and use best practices in data structures. Learn how to programmatically transform and map data from one form to another. Work effectively with researchers, IT, and systems colleagues. Automate repetitive, error prone tasks. Lesson materials are all available online, under a CC BY license, for self-directed study or for adaptation and re-use (as “Carpentries-based” training).
keywords: lessons, library, software development, data science, curriculum, Unix, Git, Python, SQL, MarcEdit, GLAM, DMP

name: HPC Carpentry
description: HPC Carpentry teaches HPC-oriented coding, and data science skills to researchers. We want to work towards bringing High Performance Computing under the Carpentries umbrella. Workshop hosts, Instructors, and learners must be prepared to follow our
keywords: hpc, data science, research software, workshop, snakemake, maestro, Python

name:
Intersect Research Software
Engineering Training
description: INTERSECT will bring together RSE instructors from multiple institutions within the U.S. to maximally exploit the capabilities, knowledge, expertise of a growing RSE community. INTERSECT will sponsor a newly-created multi-day bootcamp targeting intermediate and advanced students from U.S. institutions. The project will curate the material used in the INTERSECT workshops and training sessions while working with existing frameworks to provide an open-source platform that will allow for continued engagement with the training material and help coordinate the effort across the RSE-trainer community. In addition, INTERSECT will sponsor annual RSE-trainer workshops, focused on the curation and communal generation of training material. These workshops will connect RSE practitioner-instructors from across the country to not only leverage the knowledge of multiple institutions but also to build and strengthen the community of this group of software professionals.
keywords: research software engineer, Python, Git, PR, licensing, testing, CI/CD,

name:
The Missing
Semester of Your CS Education
description: Classes teach you all about advanced topics within CS, from operating systems to machine learning, but there’s one critical subject that’s rarely covered, and is instead left to students to figure out on their own: proficiency with their tools. We’ll teach you how to master the command-line, use a powerful text editor, use fancy features of version control systems, and much more! Students spend hundreds of hours using these tools over the course of their education (and thousands over their career), so it makes sense to make the experience as fluid and frictionless as possible. Mastering these tools not only enables you to spend less time on figuring out how to bend your tools to your will, but it also lets you solve problems that would previously seem impossibly complex.
keywords: shell, vim, data, cli, Git

name: Green Software Practitioner
description: Introduction to green software, a carbon-efficient software, meaning it emits the least carbon possible. Only three activities reduce the carbon emissions of software; energy efficiency, carbon awareness, and hardware efficiency. This training will explain all of these concepts, how to apply them to your processes and how to measure them, as well as some of the international guidelines and organizations that guide and monitor this space.
keywords: climate science, software design, data center
